Knowledge Point: A simplified template of the clause structure is given in~(\ref{exe:clstr}). A large number of clausal modifiers, including aspect, mood, modal markers and adverbials, occur in different slots in the clause and are described in Chapter~\ref{ch:clausmod}. Many adverbials, aspect markers and mood markers attach to the predicate. The predicate can be complex and is, except in Chapter~\ref{ch:clausmod}, discussed in Chapter~\ref{ch:verbs} and Chapter~\ref{ch:svc}. In this chapter, I focus on simple verbal and non-verbal predicates.

Subject and object are formally differentiated by constituent order and object marking (=at) on the last constituent of the object NP. (\ref{exe:tr}) and (\ref{exe:intr}) illustrate these characteristics for a transitive and intransitive clause, respectively.
Content 1: \gll bal se sor=at koraru | \gls dog IAM fish=OBJ bite | \glt `The dog has bitten the fish.'
Content 2: \gll in se min | \gls 1PL.EXCL IAM sleep | \glt `We slept.'

Knowledge Point: All intransitive clauses display this pattern irrespective of whether the subject is volitional/actor or non-volitional/undergoer. Active participants such as `they' in~(\ref{exe:SV3}) are formally the same as the undergoer participants such as `he' in~(\ref{exe:SV1}) and `grass' in~(\ref{exe:SV2}), that is, they are unmarked.

Transitive clauses have two arguments: subject and object. The unmarked constituent order is SOV (APV), although the object can be fronted for \is{focus}focus, which is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:APV2}) and further described in §\ref{sec:leftd} below. The object is marked with an object enclitic =at (\ref{sec:at}), also if it is pronominal, as in~(\ref{exe:APV3}).\is{transitive clause}
Content 1: \gll Mujim=at in tok nawanggar | \gls Mujim=OBJ 1PL still wait | \glt `For Mujim we're still waiting.'
Content 2: \gll bal ma=at sarie | \gls dog 3SG=OBJ follow | \glt `The dog follows him.'

Knowledge Point: The first strategy, with object marker =at on both theme\is{theme} and recipient\is{recipient}, was elicited with the verbs naunak `to show', kiempanaet `to send' and kama `to send'. The constituent order can be either agent-theme-recipient-verb (ATRV) or agent-recipient-theme-verb (ARTV), as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:naunak}).

In elicitation it was easy to get all three participants mentioned, but in the corpus the theme is almost always elided, as in~(\ref{exe:naunakte}). The theme, the object that the speaker wants the addressee to show, is clear from the context.
Content 1: \gll ka\textsubscript{A} enem=at\textsubscript{R} naunak=te | \gls 2SG woman=OBJ show=IMP | \glt `You show [it] to the woman!'

Knowledge Point: The second strategy, with the recipient marked with animate locative =konggo or lative =kongga, can be used with (at least) parin `to sell', jie `to buy', gerket `to ask' and toni `to say'. (\ref{exe:angonggoparin}) shows an object marker on the theme and a locative marker on the pronoun. (\ref{exe:esunkonggara}), on the other hand, has the number object -i suffix on the number (as in~\ref{exe:kamat} above) and both locative and object marking on the recipient. The constituent order is agent-theme-recipient-verb, and in this case theme and recipient cannot be swapped.
Content 1: \gll ma\textsubscript{A} sor=at\textsubscript{T} an=konggo\textsubscript{R} parin | \gls 3SG fish=OBJ 1SG=AN.LOC sell | \glt `He sells me fish.'
Content 2: \gll tumun me me\textsubscript{A} don kon-i=a\textsubscript{T} esun-kongga=at=a\textsubscript{R} gerket | \gls child DIST TOP thing one-PLNK=FOC father.3POSS-AN.LAT=OBJ=FOC ask | \glt `The child asks its father a thing.'
Content 3: \gll ma\textsubscript{A} reitkon purap-i\textsubscript{T} an=at\textsubscript{R} kama=et | \gls 3SG hundred fifty-OBJQNT 1SG=OBJ send=IRR | \glt `He sent me one hundred and fifty [thousand rupiah].'

Knowledge Point: The verb for `give' is a zero morpheme that requires three arguments.\footnote{Other languages with a zero morpheme for `give' are the Gum languages of Papua New Guinea, notably \ili{Amele} \citep{roberts1998give}, and \ili{Koasati}, a Muskogean language \citep{kimball1991koasati}.} The three participants in a give-construction\is{give-construction|(} are the agent (A), the theme (T) and the recipient (R). There are two elements that are combined in various constellations to make give-constructions. These are \is{causative}causative di= (§\ref{sec:di}) and benefactive\is{benefactive} =ki (§\ref{sec:ben}). Give-constructions differ depending on whether the recipient NP is a noun or a pronoun. Constructions with a noun as recipient take the form A T=\textsc{obj} (\textsc{caus}=)R=\textsc{ben} ∅, where the causative proclitic is optional. The benefactive =ki is obligatory here. Constructions with a pronoun as recipient take the form A T=\textsc{obj} (\textsc{caus}=)R ∅. Again, the causative proclitic is optional. Note that in the case of pronominal recipients, however, the benefactive enclitic =ki is ungrammatical. Table~\ref{tab:give} gives an overview of the possible constructions. These were elicited based on the corpus example in~(\ref{exe:give1}). All constructions in the table are found in the corpus.
Content 1: \gll ma\textsubscript{A} sandal=bon ladan=bon=at\textsubscript{T} di=teman-un=ki\textsubscript{R} ∅ | \gls 3SG sandal=COM shirt=COM=OBJ CAUS=friend-3POSS=BEN give | \glt `He gives the sandals and shirt to his friend.'

Knowledge Point: The position of the zero morpheme is after the recipient as in~(\ref{exe:main}) and~(\ref{exe:amat}), or after the benefactive if present as in~(\ref{exe:ditumunggi}). This is evident from the position of, for example, mood or negation marking. On the surface, everything that is attached to the verb is attached to the recipient, and is also sometimes morphophonologically integrated, as shown in~(\ref{exe:main}). Give-constructions may also be part of \is{predicate!complex}complex predicates (Chapter~\ref{ch:svc}), such as the one in~(\ref{exe:pada}), where the verbs are linked with predicate linker =i.
Content 2: \gll ma am=at ma ∅=\textbf{nin} | \gls 3SG breast_milk=OBJ 3SG give=NEG | \glt `She didn't give him milk.'
Content 3: \gll sor me selet-kon-i tete=ki ∅=\textbf{te} | \gls fish TOP piece-one-OBJQNT grandfather=BEN give=IMP | \glt `Give one piece of fish to grandfather!'
Content 5: \gll naman=a padanual=at \textbf{rep=i} \textbf{ka} ∅ | \gls who=FOC pandanus=OBJ get=PLNK 2SG give | \glt `Who got pandanus [leaf] and gave it to you?'

Knowledge Point: Benefactive =ki was also elicited in non-give constructions such as the one exemplified in~(\ref{exe:kiunggi}). Benefactive =ki does not occur on pronouns, parallel to =ki in give-constructions.
Content 1: \gll ma kewe giar=ten=at paruon=i kiun=ki | \gls 3SG house new=AT=OBJ make=PLNK wife.3POSS=BEN | \glt `He makes a new house for his wife.'

Knowledge Point: Zero-intransitive clauses lack an argument \parencite[][267]{dryer2007}. Typically, these are clauses about environmental conditions, which is why they may also be called ambient clauses. (\ref{exe:kalizs}) illustrates how a weather phenomenon (kalis `to rain') is expressed without argument. Other environmental conditions, such as fog, are expressed in the same way, but this is a rather marginal phenomenon in the corpus.
Content 1: \gll mu toni kalis=kin | \gls 3PL think rain={\glkin} | \glt `They think it will rain.'

Knowledge Point: The majority of elicited and natural speech comparative constructions are monoclausal, making use of lebe `to exceed', illustrated in~(\ref{exe:matlebe}) and~(\ref{exe:hargalebe}). Lebe `to exceed' is a loan from Malay lebih `more (than)', which is also used in comparative constructions in Malay varieties.
Content 1: \gll ma tanbes=ko ror mat \textbf{lebe} | \gls 3SG right=LOC tree 3SG.OBJ exceed | \glt `He's on the right, the tree exceeds him.'

Knowledge Point: A monoclausal exceed construction may also be made with nemies `to exceed', but is much less frequent (one natural speech example and one corpus example, against at least ten of each for lebe). (\ref{exe:nemies}) and (\ref{exe:nemies2}) are the two attested instances. Based on these two examples, it is possible that nemies actually has the more specific meaning `to exceed in height'.
Content 2: \gll warkin se mat \textbf{nemies} | \gls tide IAM 3SG.OBJ exceed | \glt `The tide exceeded him.'

Knowledge Point: In elicitation, speakers sometimes phrased a comparative construction with antonyms. That construction consists of two independent clauses, where one clause contains the standard and the other the comparee. This is possibly an artefact of the elicitation, which involved stimulus materials showing opposite types (e.g. a skinny and a fat person, or an old and a new house). An example of such a construction with antonymous predicates is seen in~(\ref{exe:temuncicaun}). It remains for further research whether this is a construction that is also used in naturalistic speech.

Existential and possessive clauses are expressed with existential mambon. (\ref{exe:kewmam}) is an existential clause. Possessive clauses, like~(\ref{exe:huka-ca}), also include a possessive suffix on the possessed or a possessive pronoun.
Content 1: \gll kewe metko \textbf{mambon} | \gls house DIST.LOC EXIST | \glt `There is a house there.'
Content 2: \gll ka me hukat-\textbf{ca} \textbf{mambon} | \gls 2PL TOP fishing_net-2SG.POSS EXIST | \glt `Do you have your fishing net?'

Knowledge Point: In nominal clauses, a NP headed by a noun functions as a predicate. Nominal clauses typically consist of two juxtaposed NPs, expressing an identity relationship between them. These clauses can also be called equational clauses. I analyse the first NP as the subject and the second NP as the predicate based on the fact that arguments typically precede the predicate in Kalamang. (\ref{exe:konguru}) contains two nominal clauses expressing someone's occupation, and~(\ref{exe:paskel}) the subject NP is headed by in `name'.
Content 2: \gll [dun-un in-un]\textsubscript{S} [pas Kelengkeleng]\textsubscript{Pred} | \gls opposite_sex_sibling-3POSS name-3POSS woman Kelengkeleng | \glt `His sibling's name was ``Kelengkeleng woman''.'

Knowledge Point: The predicate NP in nominal clauses may also be a possessive pronoun. An example is given in~(\ref{exe:hakin}).
Content 1: \gll karena hak inggon | \gls because task 1PL.EXCL.POSS | \glt `Because the task is ours.'

Knowledge Point: Although nominal clauses may occur without topic marker me (§\ref{sec:discme}), frequently they have one. (\ref{exe:rarait}) and~(\ref{exe:kamanget}) show two nominal clauses with me in between the subject and the predicate.
Content 1: \gll Nema namun me sontum Rarait | \gls Nema husband.3POSS TOP person Seram | \glt `Nema's husband is Seramese.'
Content 2: \gll Moktar esun me kamanget | \gls Moktar father.3POSS TOP medicine_man | \glt `Moktar's father is a medicine man.'

Knowledge Point: In equational\is{equational clause} clauses (also known as identifying clauses\is{identifying clause}), a distinction can be made between clauses of proper inclusion (where the second NP describes a set of items, also known as ascriptive clauses) and completely equational clauses. The two clause types are different in that in completely equational clauses the two NPs can be swapped, whereas this is impossible for the ascriptive clauses. This is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:realeq}) for a completely equational clause, where the two NPs are entirely coreferential and thus can be switched without problems. In~(\ref{exe:propincl}), a proper inclusive clause is given, where the first NP in example a (a schoolmaster) is part of the set in the second NP (Butonese men). Switching is ungrammatical. Otherwise, clauses of proper inclusion and completely equational clauses are syntactically the same. Note that also in these examples, me may be left out.

In demonstrative clauses, a NP headed by a demonstrative is the predicate. These clauses function as presentational clauses. An example is given in~(\ref{exe:matam}). Note that~(\ref{exe:matam}) also contains a locative clause, which will be described in §\ref{sec:locclau}.
Content 1: \gll ma tamatko ah [ma]\textsubscript{S} [me]\textsubscript{Pred} | \gls 3SG where INT 3SG DIST | \glt `Where is it? Ah, that's it.'
Content 2: \gll ma tamatko ah [ma]\textsubscript{S} [me]\textsubscript{Pred} | \gls 3SG where INT 3SG DIST | \glt `Where is it? Ah, that's it.'

Knowledge Point: The expression ma he me `that's it; that's enough' is also a demonstrative clause. (\ref{exe:mahem}) is taken from a story where a black-furred monkey wants to turn his fur white. A cuscus puts him in a cage in the rising sea, knowing that everything looks lighter under water. When the monkey sees his legs start turning white, he thinks it's enough and wants to be released.

Quantifier clauses state the quantity of something, and have a NP headed by a quantifier as the predicate. Quantifiers were discussed in Chapter~\ref{ch:quant}. A \is{numeral}numeral quantifier predicate is shown in~(\ref{exe:keretaun}) and a non-numeral quantifier is shown in~(\ref{exe:muawanbol}).
Content 1: \gll kereta-un [kansuor]\textsubscript{Pred} | \gls cart-3POSS four | \glt `It has four carts.' (lit. `Its cars are four.')
Content 2: \gll an muap-an [bolodak]\textsubscript{Pred} | \gls 1SG food-1SG.POSS just_little | \glt `As for me, I have just a little food.' (lit. `I, my food is just a little.')

Knowledge Point: Locative clauses express \is{location}location. Locative predicates are NPs that refer to a location, inflected with the locative postposition\is{postposition!locative} =ko. A NP carrying locative =ko may be preceded or followed by a verb. In such cases, I analyse the locative NP and the verb as a \is{predicate!complex}complex predicate. For the rules governing the ordering of verbs and locatives, see Chapter~\ref{ch:svc}. When a noun inflected with =ko is not preceded or followed by a verb, it is the predicate of the clause on its own, as in~(\ref{exe:keweo}).
Content 1: \gll mu toni [ma]\textsubscript{S} [kewe-ko]\textsubscript{Pred} | \gls 3SG say 3SG house-LOC | \glt `They say he is at home.'

Knowledge Point: NPs marked with the lative postposition\is{postposition!lative} =ka, which marks movement from or towards, are usually combined with other verbs. They are very seldom the predicate on their own. One such example, with =ka fused with distal demonstrative me as mengga, is given in~(\ref{exe:Manggan}), where the speaker sums up all the houses she hasn't visited yet (an action which for married women is related to a ritual\is{ritual}). The combination of lative NPs and verbs is described in Chapter~\ref{ch:svc}.
Content 1: \gll tete Manggan mu tok [mengga=nin]\textsubscript{Pred} weinun | \gls grandfather Manggan 3PL yet DIST.LAT=NEG too | \glt `[I] haven't yet been to grandfather Manggan's either.'

Knowledge Point: An equative construction is made with nain `like' as the standard marker and the similative postposition\is{postposition!similative} =kap on the standard. As with comparative constructions, there is no parameter, but the gradable property might be expressed as part of the comparee, as in~(\ref{exe:eq1}). In~(\ref{exe:eq2}), the verb bo `to go' is used to indicate growth. The sentence means literally something like `[it] has become [so that it is] like [the size of] a cassava fruit'.
Content 2: \gll se bo=te \textbf{nain} panggala naun=\textbf{kap} | \gls ASP go=\GLTE like cassava fruit=SIM | \glt `It's already becoming as big as a cassava.'

Knowledge Point: An alternative strategy is to use the Malay loan sama `same'. This was only elicited as shown in~(\ref{exe:sama}).

The similative postposition =kap can be used on its own, as in~(\ref{exe:kap22}) and~(\ref{exe:kap33}). In~(\ref{exe:kap22}), two things are compared, and in~(\ref{exe:kap33}), one person is compared to many.

In~(\ref{exe:kapnain}), =kap is used in combination with nain, which also translates as `like'. This is not uncommon in the corpus, but it is unclear what drives the choice of a double similative marking. Constructions with nain N=kap are used for equative constructions (as described in §\ref{sec:eq}), but it is common with similative constructions as well.
Content 1: \gll ka \textbf{nain} tenggeles=\textbf{kap} ka bo tenggeles=\textbf{kap}=te don kuek=te kuru luk=te yuwa | \gls 2SG like eagle=SIM 2SG go eagle=SIM={\glte} thing steal={\glte} bring come={\glte} PROX | \glt `You're like an eagle, you turn into an eagle stealing stuff and bringing it back.'

Knowledge Point: Like in equative constructions, a speaker can also opt to use the Malay loan word sama `same' in similative constructions, such that we get examples with sama nain N-kap. In~(\ref{exe:gierunggap}), the quality of rice is described, while~(\ref{exe:nainan}) is from a story where a black-furred monkey wants to get the same white fur as a cuscus. This is a rare construction, with only four occurrences in the corpus.
Nain `like' can also be used on its own. (\ref{exe:semenn}) is said two utterances after (\ref{exe:gierunggap}), by the same speaker, still discussing the quality of rice.
Similative constructions can also be used to compare entities or persons, such as God and Jesus in~(\ref{exe:isa}).
To single out referents (as in~\ref{exe:nainrehan}), a similative construction with only nain `like' can be used.

The similative constructions above do not have a demonstrative function. For that purpose, Kalamang has manner demonstratives wandi `like this' and mindi `like that', forms that are likely derived from the proximal and distal demonstratives, respectively. These can be used in combination with similative constructions, as in~(\ref{exe:nainrehan}) above. Manner demonstratives may be evoked to make similative constructions, as in~(\ref{exe:tanunkoi}), which expresses close similarity between two referents, in this case the position of a doll's arm on a picture. More information about manner demonstratives can be found in Chapter~\ref{ch:dems}.
To express sameness or true identity, i.e. where there is a single referent, kodak `just one' may be used, as in~(\ref{exe:kianbon}).

Content questions (also question-word questions, wh-questions or information questions) are formed with the question words listed in §\ref{sec:wcq}. Question words occur in the syntactic position\is{in situ} of the argument they are replacing and are typically \is{focus}focused with =a. Thus, in~(\ref{exe:nebaO}), neba `what' occurs in object position, because that is the syntactic position that the question is after. In~(\ref{exe:whereLOC}), tamatko `where' comes before the verb kos `to grow', just as any locative would. And in~(\ref{exe:whoA}), naman `who' occurs in subject position. The question posed in the narrative in~(\ref{exe:whoA}) is not answered, whereas for the other two examples the answer is also given.
Content 3: \gll \textbf{naman}=a kat sirie | \gls who=FOC 2SG.OBJ follow | \glt `Who follows you?'
Content 4: \gll \textbf{naman}=a kat sirie | \gls who=FOC 2SG.OBJ follow | \glt `Who follows you?'

Knowledge Point: \hspace*{-4pt}A subtype of content questions are conventionalised questions\is{conventionalised question} Kalamang speakers use to greet each other. Upon meeting each other outside or passing by someone's house, one asks either `what are you doing' (example~\ref{exe:geo}) or `where are you going/where are you coming from?' (example~\ref{exe:tamanggarabot}). These questions have the same syntax as normal content questions. To the question `what are you doing?' one may either answer with a verb marked with progressive =teba, or with the phrases ge o or ge mera, indicating that one does not want or feel the need to specify what one is doing.\is{conversation}

Polar questions are most commonly followed by a tag ye ge `or not'. (\ref{exe:yege}) shows a polar question answered in the negative, in this case with an inherent negative verb eranun `cannot' (the positive form is the Malay loan bisa `can', see §\ref{sec:lexicalneg} below).
A positive answer to a polar question is given in~(\ref{exe:yege2}).

Alternatively, polar questions can be formed without a tag. The clause structure is the same as in affirmative declarative clauses, but with a different intonation\is{intonation} (see §\ref{sec:inton}). (\ref{exe:ques}) illustrates a polar question and answer.
Other tags may be used to create rhetorical questions, or questions for which an affirmative answer is expected. (\ref{exe:gebare}) illustrates ge `no' which is used as a confirmation-seeking tag.

The tag e is also used to evoke agreement from the listener (see §\ref{sec:wcyesno} and §\ref{sec:idphon}). E is not only used with questions, and can also be used with declarative clauses for evoking agreement. The question in~(\ref{exe:tage}) remains unanswered.

To `right' is a confirmation-seeking tag (from Malay toh, ultimately from Dutch\il{Dutch} toch, all with the same meaning), illustrated in~(\ref{exe:tagto2}). It is also used to check whether the listener is still following along, and is often used to mark information that was previously given by the speaker, as in~(\ref{exe:tagto1}). Usually, an answer is not expected. Like the tag e, the use of to is not confined to questions, and can be a confirmation-seeking tag on declaratives as well (§\ref{sec:idphon}).
Content 1: \gll wa me nika wa me pi watko kaniet=et \textbf{to} | \gls PROX TOP fishing_line PROX TOP 1PL.INCL PROX.LOC tie=IRR right | \glt `This is fishing line, this we tie here, don't we?'
Content 2: \gll tumun opa me per nerunggo \textbf{to} | \gls child ANA TOP water inside right | \glt `So that child is in the water, you see?'

Knowledge Point: Alternative questions are questions that pose two alternatives to the addressee, who is expected to choose one. They are made with the help of the conjunction ye `or'. In~(\ref{exe:kademorye}), the addressee chooses the second alternative by repeating the proposition.

Imperatives are directive speech acts used for orders and commands\is{command} \parencite[][303]{shopen2007b}. They are marked with enclitic =te on the predicate. An imperative clause can but need not contain a subject (addressee). Compare~(\ref{exe:impw}), with subject, and~(\ref{exe:impwo}), without subject.
Content 1: \gll goras mat sirie ka menyanyi=\textbf{te} | \gls crow 3SG.OBJ order 2SG sing=IMP | \glt `The crow orders him: ``You sing!'''

Knowledge Point: Movement verbs ending in -a (e.g. sara `go up', marua `go towards sea', mia `come') have imperative forms in -ei, as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:erei}) for the imperative form of era `go up diagonally'. That example, taken from a route description given to a fictional stranger, also illustrates that imperative forms are not only used for orders, but also for hortatives\is{hortative}.
Content 1: \gll bo masikit mul-un=ka ka se [...] uriap mengga \textbf{erei} | \gls go mosque side-3POSS=LAT 2SG IAM {} street DIST.LAT ascend.IMP | \glt `Past the mosque, you go up to that street.'

Knowledge Point: Give-constructions, which have no overt verb (§\ref{sec:give}), are put in the imperative by adding the imperative enclitic =te to the recipient. Depending on whether the recipient is expressed as a pronoun or as a noun, it may or may not carry benefactive =ki. If a benefactive enclitic is present, the imperative is added to that, as in~(\ref{exe:nggite}).
Content 1: \gll Arifin se emun=at tiri pareir sor me seletkon-i tete=ki ∅=te | \gls Arifin IAM mother.3POSS=OBJ run follow fish DIST piece-OBJQNT grandfather.MLY=BEN give=IMP | \glt `Arifin ran after his mother: ``Give a piece of that fish to grandfather!'''

Subsection: Negation of declarative verbal main clauses
Knowledge Point: Negation of declarative verbal main clauses (also known as standard negation, \citealt{miestamo2005}) is achieved by adding the negator =nin to the predicate. Example~(\ref{exe:sem}) contrasts an affirmative and a negated clause with the stative verb sem `to be afraid'.

Subsection: Negation of declarative verbal main clauses
Knowledge Point: Examples~(\ref{exe:negv}) and (\ref{exe:negadj}) show a negated transitive verb and a negated intransitive stative verb. In both cases, the constituent order of the non-negated counterpart is the same.

Subsection: Negation of declarative verbal main clauses
Knowledge Point: Give-constructions, with a zero morpheme `give', can be negated by adding =nin to the zero morpheme, as in~(\ref{exe:kaanin}).

Subsection: Negation of declarative verbal main clauses
Knowledge Point: When the recipient is a noun instead of a pronoun, the recipient is followed by the benefactive enclitic =ki. In a negated clause, the zero morpheme follows the benefactive enclitic, and =nin is attached to the zero morpheme, as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:kinin}).

Subsection: Negation of declarative verbal main clauses
Knowledge Point: Negative clauses differ from affirmatives in that they do not allow the same verbal marking. The enclitic =kin (§\ref{sec:kin}), used in affirmative clauses for the expression of volition and imminent situations, is incompatible with negator =nin. This is illustrated in example~(\ref{exe:kinneg}). The range of semantic distinctions that =kin can express is lost, or underspecified, once a clause is negated (`neutralisation' in \cite{miestamo2016}).. Thus, (\ref{exe:turnin}) is ambiguous between a reading that the child does not want to eat or is not about to eat, and a plain negation of the verb `to eat', i.e. `the child does not eat'. Note that for explicitly expressing `not want', the Kalamang speaker can use a dedicated expression suka-\textsc{poss} ge, as described in §\ref{sec:lexicalneg}.
Content questions (§\ref{sec:opq}) are negated with negator =nin, as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:kabnin}).
Content 1: \gll naman=a kewe=at kabarat=\textbf{nin} | \gls who=FOC house=OBJ sweep=NEG | \glt `Who doesn't want to sweep the house?'

Knowledge Point: \is{polar question}Polar questions (§\ref{sec:polq}) are formed by adding ye ge, literally `or not', at the end of an affirmative clause, as in~(\ref{exe:yege1}). Ye ge is neutral in the sense that there is no expectation of either a positive or negative answer. Leaving ye ge out but keeping question intonation\is{intonation} is possible, but not often encountered.

Prohibitives, the negative counterpart of imperatives (§\ref{sec:impcla}), have a dedicated construction involving pronominal suffix -mun and clitic =in on the predicate. Note that a combination of -mun and negator =nin is ungrammatical. Example~(\ref{exe:proh1}) illustrates a prohibitive clause. See also §\ref{sec:proh}.

(\ref{exe:negloc}) is a negated locative, (\ref{exe:mengganin}) a negated lative demonstrative, (\ref{exe:inggonggonin}) a negated animate locative, (\ref{exe:wisenggap}) a negated similative and (\ref{exe:mindinin}) a negated manner adverbial.

Clauses with a NP as predicate, typically clauses of proper inclusion or ascriptive clauses, may be negated with negator =nin or with propositional negator ge. Consider~(\ref{exe:guruneg}). What the (pragmatic) difference between the two constructions is remains for further research.

Possessives and demonstratives in predicate function may not be negated with negator =nin, but must be negated with propositional negator ge. This is illustrated for possessive clauses in~(\ref{exe:posneg}).
While the proposition `that stuff is mine' is negated in~(\ref{exe:anggonge}), non-possession (i.e. not-having) is expressed with negative existential saerak.

Finally, existential clauses are negated with negative existential saerak. Examples~(\ref{exe:sorsaerak}) and~(\ref{exe:saerak}) show existential negation. Saerak is the opposite of existential mambon, as shown in example~(\ref{exe:mamsae}). It is ungrammatical to combine either mambon or saerak with negator =nin. Saerak has a slightly more differentiated use than mambon. For non-possession, saerak is obligatory, whereas for affirmative possessive clauses mambon only stresses the presence of a possessed item, but is not necessary to express possession.
Content 2: \gll karena pak \textbf{saerak} karek=ki=a kanie | \gls because nail NEG_EXIST string=INS=FOC tie | \glt `Because there were no nails [we] tied with string.'

Knowledge Point: The aspectual particle se `already' and the aspectual word tok `yet; still; first' combine with saerak as illustrated in~(\ref{exe:sesaerak}) and~(\ref{exe:toksaerak}): they get the meaning `not any more' and `not yet' respectively.

Suka-\textsc{poss} Verb=\textsc{neg} is a dedicated negative construction that means `to not want; to not agree'. The construction is made with the borrowed verb suka (<Indonesian suka `to like', but not in use with that meaning in Kalamang), nominalised by inflection with a possessive suffix and followed by a negated verb. It could be paraphrased as `is not of \textsc{pron}'s liking'. The third-person possessive suffix -un can be used for all subjects. A speaker can, however, choose to inflect suka with another person corresponding with the subject, as in~(\ref{exe:parinin}).
When the predicate is lacking, the construction can be made with ge `no', as in~(\ref{exe:leka}).

As for the lexical opposite of `not want; not agree', there is a verb lo `to consent; to like', but it is rather uncommon. An example is given in~(\ref{exe:lo}). Wishes and desires are more commonly expressed with volitional =kin, which is an irrealis marker that is among other functions used as a volitional marker, see example~(\ref{exe:natkin}). As we have seen in section \ref{sec:standneg}, volitional =kin and negator =nin are incompatible.

In the pair bisa `can'/eranun `cannot', we are dealing with a Malay form again, but this time for the positive form: bisa also means `can' in Malay. But whereas bisa in Malay is negated with standard negation marker tidak (tidak bisa `cannot'), Kalamang has a dedicated form, eranun. The use of eranun triggers nominalisation of the negated proposition with -un `\textsc{nmlz}'. (This is also the suffix that eranun itself seems to carry, but if that is so, it has lost its meaning.) Eranun is clause-final. Consider examples~(\ref{exe:bisa}) and~(\ref{exe:ningkabor}). One could also translate the construction Verb-\textsc{nmlz} eranun as `V-ing isn't possible', such that example~(\ref{exe:ningkabor}) translates as `toilet-going isn't possible.'

\hspace*{-5pt} The pair gonggin `to know'/komahal `to not know' is illustrated in~(\ref{exe:gonggin}) and~(\ref{exe:komahal}). Note also the colloquial yeso `don't know' in~(\ref{exe:gonggin}). This is a clause-initial \is{interjection}interjection uttered at high \is{pitch}pitch which expresses indignation, and not a verb like komahal.

Kalamang has two negative polarity\is{negative polarity} items: -barak `any' and don kon∼kon `any'. -barak `any' is a negative polarity item that has to be accompanied by a negated predicate or dedicated negative verb, such as konatnin `not see' in~(\ref{exe:lampurbarak}) or jietnin `not get' in~(\ref{exe:konbarak}). Som konbarak `no-one' in~(\ref{exe:nobody}) could be paraphrased as `not any person'.

Don kon∼kon `any' (lit `thing one∼\textsc{red}') can be used with a negative verb or negated predicate (example~\ref{exe:donkonkon}), or can be negated itself (example~\ref{exe:dkonkon2}). (For indefinite pronouns, see §\ref{sec:quantinfl}.)\is{indefinite pronoun!negation}

An example of subject elision\is{elision!subject} is given in~(\ref{exe:subel}). The first clause contains both subject and object. The object and predicate are repeated in the next clause as an instance of \is{tail-head linkage}tail-head linkage (§\ref{sec:tailhead}). In the second and third clause, the subject is elided.

In procedural descriptions, the subject may be elided throughout the whole text, being generic or non-referential \parencite[][156]{schapper2014}. Consider the beginning of the monologue of a woman explaining how to weave baskets in~(\ref{exe:zeropro}). There is no subject, and throughout the whole explanation she does not introduce one.

The first-person inclusive\is{clusivity} pronoun also occurs in a generic sense. In some stretches of discourse, it occurs once every now and then, being left out for a few clauses in a row, as in~(\ref{exe:genericwe}), a description of how traditional houses were built. Here, pi `we' does not refer to a specific group of people building a house on a specific occasion, but is a generic pronoun referring to whoever used to build houses the traditional way.
An example of object elision\is{elision!object} is given in~(\ref{exe:giergit}). The object, karek `string', is mentioned in the first clause and elided in the second.
Another example comes from a narrative of which the object is tobacco, but only has tobacco in object position three times in the beginning, given in~(\ref{exe:tabai3}).

A \is{topic}topic is ``an entity that the speaker identifies, about which information {\ob}...{\cb} is then given'' \parencite[][27]{krifka2012}. A topic may be marked by fronting the topicalised constituent. In addition, it may be marked with topic marker me (§\ref{sec:discme}). If the constituent is a subject, or a recipient in a give-construction, it is repeated in the main clause. This kind of fronting is only found with first-person pronoun an. A fronted subject is exemplified in~(\ref{exe:anmean}) and a fronted recipient in~(\ref{exe:leftd2}). Fronted objects, in contrast, are not repeated in the main clause. (\ref{exe:kiunatme}) has a fronted object with topic marker me, and~(\ref{exe:leftd3}) has a fronted object without topic marker. Topic marker me is described in §\ref{sec:discme}.

Knowledge Point: Another way to topicalise a subject is by apposition of a more specific NP to a more general NP. This is done by apposing a pronoun and a noun, where the noun specifies the referent of the pronoun. There is no pause between the two NPs. (\ref{exe:doubleA}) shows the apposition of esa main `his father' to the subject ma `he'. These constructions have been double-checked with two speakers to confirm that these are actual constructions and not repairs. In this example, the subject NPs are pronounced under one intonation contour.
In~(\ref{exe:doubleft}) there are even three juxtaposed NPs.

Anti-topics (AT) are constituents at the right edge of the clause, which serve to specify or reactivate a topic \parencite{lambrecht1981}. In~(\ref{exe:rd1}), the subject of the clause, tumun opa me `that child', is specified in the postposed NP. It is also a reactivation of the topic, which had been mentioned a few turns earlier. Note that the anti-topic is also marked with anaphoric demonstrative opa and topic marker me. In~(\ref{exe:rd2}), the object pesawat nunat `plane sounds', which was left out in the main clause, is mentioned in the postposed NP. Planes but not their sounds had been mentioned before in the narrative, so the specification at the end of the clause serves to indicate what people went to listen to.
